The third part on the characteristics of the cognized has already explained the basis of the cognized. How should the characteristics of the cognized be contemplated?
This is briefly threefold:
First, the characteristics of dependent arising, second, the characteristics of universal imagination, and third, the characteristics of perfect accomplishment.
What are the characteristics of dependent arising among these?
It refers to the various consciousnesses included in false imagination, with the store consciousness as their seeds.
What are these again?

It refers to the consciousness of the body, the possessor of the body, the experiencer, what is experienced by them, the consciousness that experiences, the consciousness of the world, the consciousness of number, the consciousness of place, the consciousness of speech, the consciousness of the distinction between self and other, and the consciousness of death and rebirth in good and evil destinies.

Among these, the consciousness of body, the consciousness of the possessor of body, the consciousness of the experiencer, the consciousness of what is experienced by it, the consciousness of the experiencer, the consciousness of the world, the consciousness of number, the consciousness of place, and the consciousness of speech, are due to the seeds of perfuming by names and expressions.
If it is the consciousness of the distinction between self and other, it is due to the seeds of perfuming by the view of self.
If it is the consciousness of death and rebirth in good and evil destinies, it is due to the seeds of perfuming by the members of existence.
Because of these consciousnesses, the characteristics of dependent arising that are included in the defilements of all realms and destinies, and are false discrimination, are all able to appear.
These consciousnesses are all included in false discrimination, have the nature of being consciousness only, are nonexistent, and are the basis for the appearance of unreal objects.
This is called the characteristic of dependent arising.
What is the imagined characteristic among these?
It is the appearance of objects as if they existed externally, while in reality there is only consciousness.
What is the perfected characteristic among these?
That is to say, in regard to the imagined pattern of dependent nature, there is an eternal non-existence of the nature of the appearance of objects.
Among these, the consciousness of the body, the possessor of the body, and the experiencer of the body should be understood as the six internal sense bases such as the eye.
The consciousness that is experienced should be understood as the six external sense bases such as form.
The consciousness that is the experiencer should be understood as the six consciousnesses such as visual consciousness.
The remaining consciousnesses should be understood as distinctions of these consciousnesses.
Moreover, all these consciousnesses are only consciousness, because there are no objects at all.
What is the analogy that illustrates this?
It should be understood that dreams, etc., illustrate this.

That is to say, just as in a dream there is absolutely no object, and there is only consciousness, although various forms, sounds, smells, tastes, tactile objects, houses, forests, land, and mountains appear as object-like images, there are absolutely no objects in this case.
By means of this analogy, it should be understood that at all times and places there is only consciousness.
The words â€œand so onâ€ in the above text indicate that there are other similes such as an illusion, a deception, a mirage, and a visual distortion.

If, as you say, in the state of waking, all time and place are like a dream and consist only of consciousness, then just as one awakens from a dream and realizes that everything in the dream consisted only of consciousness, why is it not the case that in the state of waking one has a similar realization?
The answer is that the state of true knowledge is also like this.

Just as in a dream this realization does not occur, but when one awakens from the dream, this realization occurs, in the same way, as long as one has not attained the true knowledge of the state of awakening, this realization does not occur, but when one attains the true knowledge of the state of awakening, this realization occurs.
How can one who has not attained the true knowledge of the state of awakening infer that there is only consciousness?
It can be inferred on the basis of teachings and reason.
As for the teachings, the Bhagavat said in the Scripture on the Ten Stages:
â€œThus, the three realms are all mind only.â€
The BhagavÄn also said the same thing in the Saá¹ƒdhinirmocana SÅ«tra, where Maitreya Bodhisattva asked the BhagavÄn:
Are the images that are the objects of samÄdhi different from this mind or not different?
The Buddha told Maitreya:
They are not different. Why is this?
Because those images are only consciousness.
I say that the objects of consciousness are only what appears as consciousness.
BhagavÄn!
If the images that are the objects of samÄdhi are not different from this mind, how does this mind still grasp this mind?
Maitreya!
There is no dharma that can grasp a dharma, but when this mind arises in this way, then this kind of image appears.

Just as a substance serves as a condition and one still sees the original substance, yet one says, 'I now see an image,' and also says, 'Apart from the substance, there is something else that appears as an image that is seen.'
This mind is also like this. When it arises in this way, there is a difference in similarity, with the reflected image appearing.
This is also manifested by the teachings and principles.
Why is it so?
In the concentrated mind, according to what is seen, such as the various blue and festering objects of knowledge, all are without any separate blue and festering things, but only see one's own mind.
By this principle, the bodhisattvas should be able to infer that in all consciousnesses there is only consciousness, and there are no objects.
Moreover, in this blue and festering, etc., it is not the memory consciousness that sees the object, because the present object is present.

The two memory consciousnesses accomplished through hearing and contemplation also take the past as their object, and therefore the reflected image that appears can be established as only consciousness.
By this inference, although the bodhisattvas have not yet attained true wisdom and understanding, they should be able to infer that it is only consciousness.

Thus, the various consciousnesses are like dreams, etc. In this way, eye consciousness, etc., can be established as consciousness only. Since the various consciousnesses such as the eye are material, how can it be seen that they also exist as consciousness only?
This is also like the previous [discussion] in terms of teachings and principles.
If these various consciousnesses are also in essence consciousness, why do they appear as the nature of form, persisting in a single class, and evolving in a continuous series?
This is because they serve as the basis for various defiled dharmas such as error.
If it were not so, the error of taking what is not the truth as the truth would not exist.
If this does not exist, the defilements of the two obstacles of the passions and the knowable would not exist.
If this does not exist, pure dharmas would also not exist.
Therefore, the various consciousnesses must evolve in this way.
Here there is a verse:
The disordered appearance and the disordered substance should be admitted as the consciousness of form,ğŸ”½and the consciousness of the eye, etc.
And also with non-form consciousness, if it does not exist, the other also does not exist.

Why do the consciousness of the body, the consciousness of the experiencer, the consciousness of the receiver, the consciousness of what is received, and the consciousness of the receiver all exist together in the body, turning in harmony, able to fully manifest and experience the body?
Why do consciousnesses such as the worldly consciousnesses evolve with distinctions?
Because since beginningless time, birth and death have flowed and turned without interruption;
Because the realm of sentient beings is immeasurable;
Because the world systems are immeasurable;
Because the various activities and mutual speech are immeasurable;
Because the distinctions in appropriation and enjoyment are immeasurable;
Because the distinctions in the enjoyment of the results of good and bad karma are immeasurable; Because the various distinctions in death and rebirth that are experienced are immeasurable.
Next, how are these consciousnesses established as the nature of consciousness-only?
In brief, by three aspects:
First, by consciousness-only, because there are no objects;
Second, due to the two natures, because there are two distinctions between the consciousness with characteristics and the consciousness with seeing;
Third, due to the various, because they arise with various aspects.
Why is this so?
Because all these consciousnesses are without objects, they can be established as mere consciousness.
Because there are characteristics and seeing, they can be established as two kinds:
If the eye consciousness, etc., take the consciousness of form, etc., as characteristics and the eye consciousness as seeing,
up to taking the body consciousness as seeing;
If the mental consciousness takes all the eyes as the first, and the dharmas as the last, the various consciousnesses as characteristics, and the mental consciousness as seeing.
Because this mental consciousness has discrimination, it arises resembling all consciousnesses.
Here there is a verse:
Mere consciousness is of two kinds and various. The observer's mind can enter,
By realizing it is only mind, one can also subdue and leave it behind.

Also, in this regard, there is a group of teachers who say that there is one consciousness, which, turning to this or that support, obtains this or that name, just as the action of thinking is called bodily or vocal action.
Also, when it turns to all supports, it turns as the images of two kinds of seeds:
namely, the image of the object alone and the image of discrimination.
Also, in all places, it turns as the image of the object of touch. In the realm of form, this consciousness is the support of the body, just as the other material organs are the support of the body.
There is a verse on this:
If one travels far, goes alone, has no body, and sleeps in a cave,
Taming this difficult-to-tame mind, I say is a true brahman.
Also, as a scripture says:
In this way, the objects of the activities of the five organs are each received by the mind, and the mind is their support.
Also, as it is said, in the twelve sense bases, the group of six consciousnesses is all called the mind sense base.

If you establish the Älaya consciousness as the consciousness that is the object of consciousness, you should know that the other consciousnesses are the perceiving part, and that the mental consciousness and its support are the seeing part, because the perceived part is the condition as object for the arising of the seeing part of consciousness. When it appears as an object, it can act as the support for the arising of the seeing part of consciousness.
This is called the establishment of consciousnesses as the nature of consciousness only.
How can it be known that objects that appear before us are clearly manifest but do not really exist?
As the World Honored One said:
â€œIf bodhisattvas accomplish four dharmas, they are able to understand and enter into the principle of consciousness only, in which there are no objects at all.

First, they accomplish the knowledge of the characteristics of contradictory consciousnesses, because hungry ghosts, animals, and celestials and humans, with regard to the same thing, perceive different objects of consciousness.
Second, they accomplish the knowledge that consciousness without an object can be obtained, because objects are obtained in dreams and reflections, whose conditions are past and future.

Third, it is endowed with the non-inverted cognition that should be free from the exertion of effort, because the cognition that takes the meaning as its object is non-inverted in the case of the meaning that exists, and because the cognition is true without the exertion of effort.
Fourth, it is endowed with the marvelous cognition that accompanies the three kinds of superior cognition.
What are the three?
First, for all bodhisattvas who have attained mental mastery and meditative absorption, various meanings appear in accordance with the power of their resolve.
Second, for those who have attained Å›amatha and cultivate insight, various meanings appear as soon as they direct their attention.
Third, for those who have attained the cognition free from discrimination, when the cognition free from discrimination is present, all meanings do not appear.

By means of the marvelous cognition that accompanies these three kinds of superior cognition as explained above, and by means of the three kinds of causes and conditions explained above, the principle that meanings are without meanings is established.
If the dependent nature really only consists of consciousness, and is the basis for the appearance of meanings that seem to exist externally, how is it established as the dependent nature?
For what reasons is it called dependent on others?
It is called dependent on others because it arises from the seeds of one's own perfuming and depends on conditions for arising;
Because it has no power to remain by itself after the moment of arising, it is called dependent on others.
If the imagined nature is really non-existent in the dependent on others, and appears as if it existed, how does it become imagined?
For what reasons is it called imagined?
It is called imagined because the mental consciousness imagines and gives rise to inverted appearances in innumerable ways;
Because it has no self-characteristic, and only the imagined can be obtained, therefore it is called imagined.
If the perfected nature is the eternal non-existence of the imagined in the dependent on others, how does it become perfected?
For what reasons is it called perfected?
It is called perfected because it is the nature of non-change;
Moreover, because it is the pure object, and because it is the most excellent of all good dharmas, it is called the perfected nature in the sense of most excellent.
Moreover, when there is that which is able to imagine and that which is imagined, the imagined nature is established.
What is it that is able to imagine?ğŸ”½What is it that is imagined?
What is the imagined nature?
One should know that the thinking consciousness is that which is able to imagine, because it is discriminating.
Why is this?

Because this thinking consciousness uses the perfuming of its own verbalization as a seed, and it uses the perfuming of all consciousnesses as a seed. For this reason, the thinking consciousness evolves with innumerable modes of activity and discrimination, and it imagines and discriminates everywhere. Therefore it is called imagining.
Moreover, the nature that is dependent on others is called that which is imagined.
Moreover, when, because of this characteristic, the nature that is dependent on others becomes that which is imagined, this is called the imagined nature.
By this characteristic means in this way.
Next, how does imagination thoroughly imagine?
What objects does it take as its objects?
What appearances does it grasp?
By what attachment?ğŸ”½By what does it give rise to speech?
By what does it give rise to verbal expression?
What does it increase?

It means that taking names as its objects, in the dependent nature it grasps their appearances, by seeing it becomes attached, by seeking it gives rise to speech, by the four kinds of verbal expression such as seeing, hearing, etc. it gives rise to verbal expression, and in the absence of meaning it increases it as if it existed. In this way, imagination is able to thoroughly imagine.
Next, are these three natures different or non-different?
It should be said that they are neither different nor non-different.ğŸ”½It means that the dependent nature, due to a different approach, becomes the dependent;
this very nature, due to a different approach, becomes the imagined, and this very nature, due to a different approach, becomes the perfected.
By what kind of mode does this other-dependent nature become other-dependent?
Because it arises from the seeds of perfuming of other things.
By what kind of mode does this very nature become the imagined?
Because it is the characteristic that is the object of imagination and because it is imagined by the imagination.
By what kind of mode does this very nature become the perfected?
Because it is not as it is imagined.
How many kinds are there of these three natures?
The other-dependent has two kinds:

the first is that it is born from the seeds of perfuming of other things, and the second is that it is not established as either defiled or pure, because of these two kinds of other-dependence, it is called other-dependent.
The imagined also has two kinds:
the first is the imagination of self-existence, and the second is the imagination of distinctions. Because of this, it is called the imagined.
The perfected nature also has two kinds:
First, because of the inherent nature of perfect accomplishment; second, because of the purity of perfect accomplishment. For these reasons, it is established as the nature of perfect accomplishment.
Furthermore, there are four kinds of imagination:
First, imagination of inherent nature; second, imagination of distinctions; third, imagination with awareness; fourth, imagination without awareness.
With awareness refers to those skilled in language;
Without awareness refers to those unskilled in language.
Thus, there are five kinds of imagination:ğŸ”½First, imagining the inherent nature of an object based on its name, thinking This name has such an object;

Second, imagining the inherent nature of a name based on its object, thinking This object has such a name;ğŸ”½Third, imagining the inherent nature of a name based on a name, imagining the nature of a name that has not yet been understood;
Fourth, imagining the inherent nature of an object based on an object, imagining the nature of an object that has not yet been understood;
Fifth, based on the two natures of the two kinds of imagination, namely, imagining this name and this meaning to have such a nature.
Next, all conceptualization is summarized into ten kinds:
First, fundamental conceptualization, namely the Älaya consciousness.
Second, conceptualization of objective characteristics, namely consciousnesses of form, etc.
Third, conceptualization of manifest characteristics, namely eye consciousness, etc., and the consciousnesses on which they are based.

Fourth, conceptualization of changes in objective characteristics, namely changes due to aging, changes due to pleasant feelings, etc., changes due to craving, etc., changes due to harm, changes due to the passage of time, etc., changes due to the various destinies such as the hells, and changes due to the various realms such as the desire realm.
Fifth, conceptualization of changes in manifest characteristics, namely the changes in the aforementioned changes.
Sixth, conceptualization induced by others, namely conceptualization of the kind that hears what is not the true Dharma and the kind that hears the true Dharma.
Seventh, unreasonable discrimination, referring to the discriminations of those outside the true teachings who hear non-true teachings.
Eighth, reasonable discrimination, referring to the discriminations of those within the true teachings who hear the true teachings.
Ninth, attached discrimination, referring to the discriminations associated with the sixty-two views based on the view of the aggregates as real self, which are of the class of unreasonable thought.
Tenth, agitated discrimination, referring to the ten kinds of discriminations of bodhisattvas:

First, agitation of signlessness, second, agitation of signs, third, agitation of superimposition, fourth, agitation of denial, fifth, agitation of singularity, sixth, agitation of multiplicity, seventh, agitation of intrinsic nature, eighth, agitation of distinctions, ninth, agitation of taking meaning from names, and tenth, agitation of taking names from meaning.
In order to counteract these ten kinds of agitation, all the teachings on non-discriminating cognition are found in the perfection of wisdom.
In this way, the objects of elimination and their antidotes should be understood to completely include the meaning of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
If, by means of a different approach, the dependent nature has three natures, why are the three natures not without distinction?

If, by means of a different approach, it becomes the dependent nature, it does not thereby become the imagined and the perfected;ğŸ”½If, by means of a different approach, it becomes the imagined, it does not thereby become the dependent and the perfected;
If, by means of a different approach, it becomes the perfected, it does not thereby become the dependent and the imagined.
Next, how can it be known that, as for the dependent nature, the imagined nature appears but does not correspond to its essence?
Because prior to the name, there is no cognition, which contradicts correspondence to the essence;
Because there are many names, it contradicts having many essences;
Because the name is not definite, it contradicts a mixed essence.
Here there are two verses:
Because of the absence of cognition before the name, the multiplicity of names, and the uncertainty,
The establishment of the name as the essence, the multiplicity of essences, and the mixture of essences are contradictory.
Dharmas are nonexistent yet can be obtained, unstained yet have purity,
One should know they are like illusions and so forth, and also similar to space.
Next, why is it that the reality as it appears does not exist at all, yet the dependent nature is not entirely nonexistent?
If this [dependent nature] were nonexistent, the perfected nature would also be nonexistent;
If this [perfected nature] were nonexistent, then everything would be nonexistent.
If the dependent nature and the perfected nature did not exist, there would be the error of being neither defiled nor purified.
Since defilement and purification are presently obtained, therefore everything should not be nonexistent.
Here there is a verse:
If the dependent nature did not exist, the perfected nature would also not exist,
If all kinds were non-existent, there would be no defilement or purity at any time.
The buddhas, the world-honored ones, in the Mahayana teach the vaipulya sutras. In those sutras it is said:
How should one understand the imagined nature?
It should be understood as non-existent according to different approaches.
How should one understand the other-dependent nature?
It should be understood as being like an illusion, a mirage, a dream, an image, a reflection, an echo, the moon in the water, and a transformation.
How should one understand the perfected nature?
It should be understood as being the teaching of the four pure dharmas.
What are the four pure dharmas?
First, the pure nature, which refers to suchness, emptiness, the ultimate reality, signlessness, and the dharma realm.
Second, the pure separation from defilements, which refers to the separation from all the defilements of hindrances.
Third, the pure attainment of the path, which refers to all the factors of enlightenment, the perfections, and so forth.
Fourth, the arising of this realm is pure, referring to the marvelous and correct teachings of the Mahayana.
Because of this pure condition, it is not the nature of imagination;
because it is the nature of the outflow of the most pure Dharma realm, it is not the nature of dependent arising.
In this way, these four dharmas comprehensively include all pure dharmas without exception.
Here there are two verses:
Illusion and so forth are said to be arising;ğŸ”½It is said that there is no imagined nature. If the four purities are spoken of,
This is called the perfected nature.
The nature, the stainless, the pure, and the object of the path,
All pure dharmas are all included in the four characteristics.
Next, why are the analogies of illusion and so forth spoken of in the sutra regarding the nature of dependent arising?
In order to remove others' false doubts regarding the nature of dependent arising.
How do others have false doubts regarding the nature of dependent arising?
Because others have doubts like this regarding this:
How can there be no real objects and yet have objects of activity?
In order to eliminate this doubt, the analogy of a magical creation is given.
How can there be no objects and yet have the arising of mind and mental factors?
In order to eliminate this doubt, the analogy of a mirage is given.
How can there be no objects and yet have the distinction of pleasant and unpleasant experiences?
In order to eliminate this doubt, the analogy of a dream is given.
How can there be no objects and yet have the distinction of good and bad actions producing pleasant and unpleasant results?
In order to eliminate this doubt, the analogy of a reflection is given.
How can there be no objects and yet have the arising of various consciousnesses?
In order to eliminate this doubt, the analogy of a light and its reflection is given.
How can there be no objects and yet have the arising of various conceptual proliferations and verbal expressions?
In order to eliminate this doubt, the analogy of an echo is given.
How can there be no objects and yet have the arising of the objects of activity of the various samÄdhis that are actually grasped?
In order to eliminate this doubt, the analogy of the moon in the water is given.
How can there be no objects and yet have bodhisattvas, with minds free from error, intentionally take birth in order to accomplish the benefit and happiness of sentient beings?
In order to eliminate this doubt, the analogy of transformation is given.
Based on what hidden meaning did the World-Honored One say in the Brahma's Questions Sutra:
The Tathagata does not attain birth and death, nor does he attain nirvana?
In the dependent nature, based on the imagined nature and the perfected nature, there is the hidden meaning of the non-difference between birth and death and nirvana.
Why is it so?
Because this dependent nature, due to the imagined nature, becomes birth and death, and due to the perfected nature, becomes nirvana.
In the Abhidharma Mahayana Sutra, the Bhagavat said:
There are three kinds of dharmas:
1. The defiled aspect, 2. The pure aspect, 3. The aspect of those two.
Based on what hidden meaning is this said?
In the dependent nature, the imagined nature is the defiled aspect, the perfected nature is the pure aspect, and the dependent itself is the aspect of those two;
Based on this hidden meaning, it is said like this.
In this meaning, what metaphor is used to illustrate it?
Using the metaphor of a treasure of gold and soil to reveal it.
It is like the three dharmas that can be obtained in the treasure of gold and soil in the world:
First, the earth element; second, soil; third, gold.
In the earth element, soil is not really existent but can be obtained, while gold is really existent but cannot be obtained;
When burned and refined by fire, the appearance of soil does not appear, while the appearance of gold becomes manifest.

Moreover, this earth element, when the appearance of soil is manifest, is falsely manifest, and when the appearance of gold is manifest, it is truly manifest. Therefore, the earth element is the two parts of them.

Consciousness is also like this. When the fire of non-discriminating cognition has not yet burned, in this consciousness, all false imaginations and attachments appear, while all that is real, the perfect and accomplished nature, does not appear.

When this consciousness is burned by the fire of nondiscriminative cognition, the true perfect nature that exists in this consciousness becomes manifest, while the false imagined nature does not become manifest.
Therefore this consciousness that is imagination of the unreal and is the relative nature has these two parts, like the earth element in a treasure house of gold and dirt.

The World-Honored One has said in some places that all dharmas are permanent, in some places that all dharmas are impermanent, and in some places that all dharmas are neither permanent nor impermanent. On the basis of what hidden meaning does he speak in this way?

He means that the relative nature has as its part the perfect nature, which is permanent, has as its part the imagined nature, which is impermanent, and has as its two parts that are neither permanent nor impermanent.
He speaks in this way on the basis of this hidden meaning.
Just as permanence and impermanence are not two, so also suffering and happiness are not two;ğŸ”½purity and impurity are not two;
emptiness and nonemptiness are not two;
Self and non-self are non-dual;
Tranquil and not tranquil are non-dual;
Having intrinsic nature and lacking intrinsic nature are non-dual;
Arising and non-arising are non-dual;
Cessation and non-cessation are non-dual;
Originally tranquil and not originally tranquil are non-dual;
Natural nirvÄá¹‡a and not natural nirvÄá¹‡a are non-dual;
Saá¹ƒsÄra and nirvÄá¹‡a are also non-dual in the same way.
Such distinctions, the secret words of all buddhas, should be understood according to the three intrinsic natures, as explained above through the gates of permanence, impermanence, and so forth.
Here there are many verses:
Just as phenomena are not real, they appear not as one kind;
Not phenomena, not non-phenomena, thus the meaning of non-duality is explained.
Based on one aspect, it is revealed as either existent or non-existent;
Based on two aspects, it is said to be neither existent nor non-existent.
As it does not exist as it appears, therefore it is said to be non-existent.
Because it appears in this way, therefore it is said to exist.
The nature of self and substance is non-existent, the intrinsic nature does not abide firmly,
As it is not as it is grasped, therefore it is accepted as having no intrinsic nature.
Because of having no intrinsic nature, it is accomplished, and is the basis for what follows,
Without arising or ceasing, originally quiescent, with the intrinsic nature of nirvana.
Moreover, there are four kinds of intentions and four kinds of secrets, all the words of the Buddha should be understood according to them.
The four intentions are:
1. The intention of equality, which is like saying:
In the past, at that time and in that life, I was named VipaÅ›yin, the Perfectly Enlightened One.
2. The intention of different times, which is like saying:

And like what is said:
By merely making a vow, one can be reborn in the Land of Ultimate Bliss.
Third, the intention of special meaning, which refers to statements such as:
Only after encountering and serving as many buddhas as the sands of the Ganges River can one understand the meaning of the MahÄyÄna teachings.
Fourth, the intention of the inclinations of individuals, which refers to praising giving to one person first and then later criticizing it;
Just as with giving, one should understand that this is also the case with precepts and a portion of cultivation.
These are called the four intentions.
As for the four secrets,

the first is the secret of entry, which refers to in the ÅšrÄvakayÄna or the MahÄyÄna, according to the truth of conventional reality, it is said that there are individuals and the self-natures and distinctions of various dharmas.
The second is the secret of characteristics, which refers to in this context, the characteristics of dharmas are explained, revealing the three natures.
The third is the secret of antidotes, which refers to in this context, the practice of antidotes is explained, with eighty-four thousand [methods].
Fourth, the secret of transformation, which means that in this place, with its different meanings, various words and letters manifest different meanings.
As a verse says:
Awakening to what is not solid as solid, well abiding in the inverted,
Extremely afflicted by afflictions, attaining supreme enlightenment.
If one wishes to compose a commentary on the MahÄyÄna Dharma, it should be composed in brief by means of three aspects:
First, by explaining dependent origination; second, by explaining the characteristics of dharmas produced from conditions; third, by explaining the meaning of the words.
Here, explaining dependent origination means, as it is said:
The dharmas produced by the perfuming of words arise from that,
Maturation and the evolving consciousnesses mutually give rise to each other as conditions.
Furthermore, the characteristics of those evolving consciousnesses and dharmas have characteristics, have views, and have consciousness as their nature.

Moreover, they take the basis as their characteristic, the imagined as their characteristic, and the nature of dharmas as their characteristic. For this reason, it shows the characteristics of the three natures.
As it is said:
From the existent characteristic, there is the view. One should know that those three characteristics
Moreover, how should one explain their characteristics?
It means that the characteristic of the imagined is truly non-existent within the characteristic of the dependent on others;
The characteristic of the perfected is truly existent within it.
Because of these two kinds of non-existence and existence, non-attainment and attainment, those who have not yet seen and those who have already seen the truth are simultaneous.
It means that within the nature that is dependent on others, there is no imagined, and therefore there is perfected.
When revolving in this way, if one attains that, one does not attain this; if one attains this, one does not attain that.
As it is said:
The dependent and the grasped are non-existent, and the perfected exists within them.
Therefore, attainment and non-attainment, within them, the two are equal.
As for explaining the meaning of the words, it means first explaining the initial phrase, and then using the remaining phrases to analyze and reveal.
Either by means of the qualities or by means of the meaning.
As for by means of the qualities, it refers to explaining the Buddha's merits:

It is said that it is by means of the six perfections of giving, morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom.
How does one enter into consciousness-only by means of the six perfections?
Moreover, how do the six perfections become the fruit of that entry?

It is said that when this bodhisattva is not attached to wealth and status, does not violate morality, is unmoved by suffering, is not lax in cultivation, and does not engage in the causes of distraction such as these, the mind becomes focused on a single object and is able to discern phenomena according to principle and enter into consciousness-only.
Having entered into consciousness-only by means of the six perfections, the bodhisattva realizes the six perfections that are included in the pure superior intention.

Therefore, even if one is separated from the six perfections in the present practice, by attaining understanding of the holy teachings and by cherishing, rejoicing, and delighting in the contemplations, one always constantly and uninterruptedly practices the six perfections with appropriate means, and quickly perfects them.

For what reasons are there only six perfections in number?
Because they establish the antidotes to the obstacles that are to be counteracted.
Because they are the basis for realizing the Buddha Dharma, and because they follow along with and mature all sentient beings.
In order to counteract the causes for not setting out, one establishes the perfections of giving and morality.
The causes for not setting out are attachment to wealth and status, and attachment to family.
In order to counteract the causes for turning back even though one has already set out, one establishes the perfections of patience and vigor.

The causes for turning back are the various sufferings produced by sentient beings in the course of transmigration, and the fatigue produced by the practice of wholesome activities over a long period of time.
In order to counteract the cause of loss and destruction even though one has already set out and does not regress, one establishes the perfections of concentration and wisdom.
The cause of loss and destruction refers to distraction and wrong wisdom.
Thus, the establishment of antidotes to counter obstacles is only six in number.
Moreover, the first four perfections are the causes of non-distraction, and the next perfection is the accomplishment of non-distraction.
Relying on this non-distraction, one truly realizes the true meaning of all dharmas, and is then able to realize all Buddha-dharmas.
Thus, the basis for realizing all Buddha-dharmas is only six in number.
Due to the perfection of giving, one is able to properly embrace all sentient beings;

Because of the perfection of vigor, one is able to assist in the management of what should be done.
Just by these causes and conditions of embracing and benefiting, one enables all sentient beings to be capable of the work of maturation.

From this point on, those whose minds are not yet concentrated are caused to attain concentration, and those whose minds are already concentrated are caused to attain liberation. At the time of enlightenment, they attain maturity.

How can the distinctions among these perfections be seen?
It should be known that each has three grades.

The three grades of morality are: first, the morality of restraining from wrongdoing, second, the morality of accumulating good dharmas, and third, the morality of benefiting sentient beings.

The three grades of patience are: first, the patience of enduring harm from others, second, the patience of peacefully accepting suffering, and third, the patience of contemplating the truth of dharmas.

The three grades of vigor are: first, the vigor of donning armor, second, the vigor of practice, and third, the vigor of being without cowardice, without turning back, and without being content with little.
